steps.title: Put the bib 4 inches (10 cm) - 5 inches (13 cm) below your collar bone.
steps.content: Put the bib 4 inches (10 cm) - 5 inches (13 cm) below your collar bone. The bib is the top part of the apron that covers your chest. You don’t want it too high, because it will strangle you. If you put it too low, it will not effectively keep your shirt clean.

steps.title: Tie a knot in the back of the loop if the apron has a single bib loop.
steps.content: Tie a knot in the back of the loop if the apron has a single bib loop. Place the loop over your head. Find the right height for your bib. Tie a knot at the back of the loop to shorten it so your apron hangs where you want it to hang. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Thread the tie through the loop if the apron has a tie/loop closure.
steps.content: Thread the tie through the loop if the apron has a tie/loop closure. Start by placing the tie around your neck, then threading it through the loop. Position the bib where you want it. Then tie the loose end around the loop and onto itself.

steps.title: Cut the neck loop and tie a knot if you have a long single neck loop.
steps.content: Cut the neck loop and tie a knot if you have a long single neck loop. Start by cutting the neck look in half at the midpoint. Position your bib, then tie the two strings in a knot behind your neck. Make sure you can get the apron on and off over your head before you cut the strings. Cut the extra, dangling parts of the strings so they don’t look sloppy or interfere with your work.

steps.title: Bring your apron’s strings together in the back.
steps.content: Bring your apron’s strings together in the back. Take one tie in each hand and bring them together behind you. Make sure your ties are not overly twisted, though a few twists won’t matter. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tie them together using a knot or a bow.
steps.content: Tie them together using a knot or a bow. Pull the ties together before you start your knot so that your apron is tight. Don’t make it so tight that you can’t breathe or you feel like you’re cutting off circulation. [3] X Research source Tie the strings in a shoelace knot or a half-shoelace knot.

steps.title: Tug on your knot to test its strength.
steps.content: Tug on your knot to test its strength. Pull on your apron lightly from the top and the bottom. You don’t want a knot that’s going to fall out while you’re working! If it does fall out, redo it until it doesn’t.

steps.title: Practice tying with your eyes closed to get faster.
steps.content: Practice tying with your eyes closed to get faster. Many people struggle with tying behind their own backs. To practice, take your apron off and lay it on a table in front of you. Take one tie in each hand, close your eyes, and practice tying them until it becomes easier.

steps.title: Test to see if the apron falls above or below your knees.
steps.content: Test to see if the apron falls above or below your knees. Put on your neck loop and tie it as you plan to wear it. If you have a half apron, hold it at your waist where you plan to wear it. Look in a mirror and see if your apron hangs below your knees. If your apron hangs below your knees, you can hem it with some scissors and a sewing machine or hemming tape. [4] X Research source If you don’t want to sew or you don’t have time, just grab the apron at the hips and fold a section up. Hold this in place while you tie and you have shortened your apron.

steps.title: Cross your apron’s ties behind you and bring them around to the front.
steps.content: Cross your apron’s ties behind you and bring them around to the front. Take one tie in each hand. Pass them behind your back, switching hands as you do so, and bring them to the front again. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tie your apron in a knot or a bow.
steps.content: Tie your apron in a knot or a bow. Pull the ties tight before you tie, but not so tight that you can’t breathe. [6] X Research source You can use a shoelace knot, a slip knot, or even a half-hitch knot. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Test your knot for strength by pulling on it gently.
steps.content: Test your knot for strength by pulling on it gently. Tug on your apron gently from both the top and the bottom. If your knot falls out, redo the process with tighter ties or a different kind of knot.
